metadata.purpose: Demonstrate proper use of semantic annotations and ontology identifiers

skos_definition.en: The present value of expected cash flows minus the initial investment cost, used to evaluate the profitability of an investment or project

skos_scope_note.en: NPV is a primary method in capital budgeting for evaluating long-term investments. A positive NPV indicates the investment is expected to add value to the firm.

definition.primary: Net Present Value (NPV) is the difference between the present value of cash inflows and the present value of cash outflows over a period of time. NPV is used in capital budgeting and investment planning to analyze the profitability of a projected investment or project.
definition.technical: NPV represents the sum of all discounted future cash flows minus the initial investment, where cash flows are discounted using an appropriate discount rate (typically the cost of capital or required rate of return).
definition.simple: NPV tells you how much value an investment will add to your company in today's money. If NPV is positive, the investment is good; if negative, avoid it.

decision_rule.accept: If NPV > 0, accept the project (creates value)
decision_rule.reject: If NPV < 0, reject the project (destroys value)
decision_rule.ranking: When choosing between mutually exclusive projects, select the one with highest NPV

components.name: Cash Flows (CF_t)
components.description: Expected future cash inflows and outflows from the investment
estimation_challenges: Incremental cash flows vs. total cash flows

components.name: Discount Rate (r)
components.description: The required rate of return or cost of capital used to discount future cash flows

components.name: Initial Investment (I₀)
components.description: The upfront cost required to start the project at time zero

components.name: Time Period (t)
components.description: The timing of each cash flow, typically measured in years

example_calculation.interpretation: This investment is expected to add $28,791.31 in value (in present value terms) to the firm.

advantages: Accounts for time value of money
Considers all cash flows over project life
Allows comparison of different-sized projects when using profitability index
limitations: Requires accurate cash flow estimates (difficult to forecast)
Choice of discount rate is subjective and critical
Does not account for project flexibility or real options
May not work well for comparing mutually exclusive projects of different sizes or durations
Assumes cash flows can be reinvested at the discount rate

related_concepts.name: Internal Rate of Return (IRR)
related_concepts.relationship: Alternative capital budgeting metric that finds the discount rate where NPV = 0
related_concepts.comparison: IRR gives a percentage return, NPV gives absolute dollar value. NPV is generally preferred when conflicts arise.

related_concepts.name: Payback Period
related_concepts.relationship: Simpler metric that measures time to recover initial investment
related_concepts.comparison: Payback ignores time value of money (unless discounted), while NPV accounts for it.

related_concepts.name: Profitability Index (PI)
related_concepts.relationship: Ratio of PV of cash flows to initial investment (PI = NPV/I₀ + 1)
related_concepts.comparison: PI is useful for ranking projects when capital is limited; NPV shows absolute value added.

related_concepts.name: Present Value (PV)
related_concepts.relationship: NPV is the sum of PVs minus initial investment

references.title: Principles of Corporate Finance
references.chapter: Net Present Value and Other Investment Criteria

usage_notes.for_developers: This AKU demonstrates comprehensive semantic annotation with FIBO, Wikidata, and DBpedia links. Copy the semantic_links structure for your own NPV-related AKUs.
usage_notes.for_educators: Use this as a complete reference for teaching NPV. Adjust content.definition levels based on audience (primary for undergrads, technical for grad students, simple for high school).
usage_notes.for_knowledge_graph: The semantic_links section enables automatic linking to other ontologies and multilingual rendering. The @id serves as the internal node identifier.
